Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Michael J. Griffin is "Harmonic Maass Forms." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Shou-Wu Zhang.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I work in areas of number theory related to harmonic Maass forms, modular forms, and elliptic curves. These objects play important roles in a surprisingly diverse array of subjects including class field theory, arithmetic geometry, representation theory, knot theory, string theory, etc. My work has focused on problems in these areas including Jensen polynomials for the Riemann zeta function, Gross-Zagier style theorems for derivatives of L-functions of elliptic curves, class numbers, moonshine phenomena relating representations of groups to modular forms, and Rogers–Ramanujan type identities. Many questions remain in these areas that warrant further research, and I intend to continue my work in these areas with collaborators and students.

 

Over the past few years under the support of the NSF, I have worked as a postdoc at Princeton University (Fall 2015-Summer 2016) under the advisement of Dr. Shou Wu Zhang and at the Universität zu Köln (Fall 2016 - Summer 2017), under the advisement of Kathrine Bringmann. Two years ago (Fall 2017) I began working as an assistant professor at Brigham Young University, and I used my final partial-year of NSF funding to support my research and reduce my teaching load at BYU.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Over the course of this grant, I have completed four publications, along with four others nearing completion. The four completed papers are:

  • M. Griffin, L. Rolen, K. Ono, and D. Zagier, Jensen polynomials for Riemann’s zeta function and suitable arithmetic sequences, PNAS 116 no. 23 (2019), 11103-11110.
  • J. Chahal, M. Griffin, N. Priddis, When are multiples of polygonal numbers again polygonal numbers?, Hardy–Ramanujan Journal. 41 (2018), 58-67.
  • M. Griffin, M. Mertens, A proof of the Thompson Moonshine conjecture, Research in the Mathematical Sciences. 3:36 (2016).
  • M. Griffin, On p-adic Harmonic Maass Functions, Submitted.

I have also presented talks at eight conferences and given invited seminars or colloquia at three universities.

 

Broader Impacts:

While positioned at Princeton, I volunteered at the Museum of Math with one of their after-school groups for middle-school students. During the past two years at BYU I lead the high school group of our department’s summer math camp. In that time, I have also been the coach of our university’s math competition team. I am currently working with one master student and two undergraduate research students. BYU places a high emphasis on undergraduate research. I benefited immensely from this program when I was a student at BYU, and I am committed to continuing that work with undergraduates. Besides working with my own students, I am also an active participant in our computational number theory student seminar which is regularly attended by six to twelve undergraduates at various levels, interested in number theory.
